title: The one thing League of Legends is lacking....
body: In your client we should have a bar that tells us what our ping is prior to starting a game. Like a little bar next to the play button that displays what our current ping is, I think this would help TREMENDOUSLY so I can stop playing Russian roulette with my games. What do you think of my idea?

From a technical standpoint I agree with you, but there is a work around too. Which is instead of having the ping be displayed while just idling they add it to the lobby's above were you invite people or before you click to play a game. That way people that will be pinging the server anyways (ie those about to start games) are the only ones that can see their ping. This would allow people to check their pin before games while not severely screwing riots servers
A ping display on the accept/cancel popup would be pretty nice to have.

Everyone who's logged in is already constantly pining the servers.  That's how your buddy list gets updated every time someone enters a game or logs on/off.  That's how you send and receive chat with other players.  That's how you get all that content on the home page of the client (except for youtube, that's coming from google).

A quick ping test when you click "Play" to show your ping before you start a match would cost Riot just about nothing and would help players with shotty connections know if a game right now is a good idea or not.
How would it help to ping the client servers? They're completely different from the game servers and it wouldn't help anyone in any way. If you want to check your own connection just ping google.

Googles servers are not in the same building as the League of Legends game servers.  The Riot client servers are.  There could be a problem somewhere between me and Riot's server farm that doesn't exist between my machine and google.
Are you joking? How often do you think the client sends a request to the server, requesting messages, etc. You can just measure the response time from one of those requests.
It's not pinging the game servers, it's pinging the matchmaking or client servers. For measuring the stability of game servers it's completely useless.

Ping is the time it takes for information to get to a server and back again.  The game serves, matchmaking servers, and so on are all in the same server farm.  If it takes 80 ms to reach the chat server you can damn well bet it takes the same time to reach the game servers.

If the game server is unstable that is a completely different problem.

Actually, that's latency. Pinging is just the process you normally use to determine your latency and some people call latency ping.
What's your point? Unless you moved recently you should already know what your average in-game ping is when both your connection and the servers are stable. Therefore a system like this gives you no useful information you couldn't get otherwise. You can check the stability of your own connection without it and you can't check the stability of the game servers anyway.

If you want to get super technical ping is a query to determine if a connection exists between two given computers.  The value of displaying ping time before someone gets in game would be for people who, like the OP, have unreliable connections.

I have a friend on Comcast, for example.  Most of the time it's ok but maybe three hours a week they find their packets getting sent from California to New York on their way to Riots servers.  A ping indicator when starting a game would help avoid playing under these ... less then desirable conditions.

Then ping the login gateways, that's in the same location. You can find the IPs with some light googling. Or use tracert to trace the signal. It's really not that complex, If all you want is a test from your location to Riot client servers you can do it yourself pretty easily.
You seem vehemently opposed to the idea of Riot building in a feature to let players know their ping before they play.  If you don't mind my asking, why is that?

Because you can already do it. It's just like people crying for an official replay system when there are a shitton of sites or programs that can easily provide and store your replays already.

There's nothing Riot can do that you can't do yourself or with 3rd party sites already. The only thing you can't do is ping game servers and being able to do that would just put more stress on them.

You are right. Everybody can probably do it. But how many people actually do?

I'd like to know the ping/latency/whatever of all my teammates before starting a game. Ideally, if someone is having some network problem, the game would give me the option to legally dodge the match, marking the person with the problem so they wont queue with me any time soon. But we are talking about Rito, so, just the ping information would be good enough...

Just because people are too stupid to do anything by themselves doesn't mean they should be spoonfed.

Also, you used to be able to see teammate ping while loading, it was removed intentionally because it was causing toxic behaviour.

That's why this information should be visible **before** the game, not when there is noting you can do to avoid the match.

Also, quoting your self:

"There's nothing Riot can do that you can't do yourself or with 3rd party sites already."

Could you please give me a link to a site or software that shows me the latency between my teammates and Rito's servers?
If there was such a site riot would probably take it down. They removed teammate and enemy ping for a reason, it's not coming back.

What am I, your computer science teacher? Just google it, don't be so lazy. And it's not just about riot shutting websites down, the websites need access to the Riot API to even work in the first place. And to get that you'd need to talk to Riot and convince them that your site would be useful to the community. So you'd need access to the API and you'd need proof that your website is useful once it's up. If you do it just for yourself or do something Riot doesn't agree with you won't be able to access their API anymore.

Obviously they wouldn't agree as they removed a feature like that and have no reason to change that.

So, are you saying that probably there is somehow a way to make a site that shows me my teammates latency between their computer and Riot's servers? Such site doesn't exist just because Riot would shut it down?

Would you please enlighten me about such technology should I use. I guarantee that I'll build it myself and run it locally...

And just because they removed a feature, it doesn't mean that this feature can not reevaluated and redesigned to serve in a better purpose. 

You sir have a slightly pessimistic way of thinking...

That's like saying a government shouldn't bother to build and maintain a military for defense because we can hire mercenaries anyways. Why should they be bothered to do that when I have 3rd party sites(soldiers) to do it for them? (it's not a direct importance link, but it's the same idea- we can do the same things, but have to use something else to do it.)
So would it be more appropriate to blame Comcast or Riot servers for my unforgiving latency and frequent disconnects?

Probably Comcast but you'd need to test to know for sure.  [Traceroute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traceroute) is your friend here.  If you open a command prompt and traceroute (or tracert on Windows) 216.52.241.254 then you should be able to see where your packets are going and what jumps are taking the longest.  

It takes some work but if things are working correctly each hop should have a low latency time and they should generally be headed towards Riot's servers.

The first problem is easy to see.  If one hop is taking a long time that's probably where the lag is coming from.  If that hop is somewhere in Comcast's network then it's their fault.  If it's somewhere close to the end of the line then the problem is Riot or their ISP.

The second problem can take more work to suss out but if you look up the internet providers your data is passing through you can figure out if your packets are taking a wrong turn somewhere.  I have yet to see this problem caused by anyone but Comcast but there's always room for new things in the world.
